Articles.Content: I don't know how many people there were but someone tried to steal a bike from our backyard. The one in our backyard managed to get away, and we've got the bike.

>

Not here in 'Merica, you have the right to 'stand your ground' (read: shoot trespassers) in most states.

> 
> Not here in 'Merica, you have the right to 'stand your ground' (read: shoot trespassers) in most states.

That's not entirely true. SOME states have strong castle doctrine, which does indeed state that if someone intrudes into your home, lethal response is allowed. In some places, this protection is extended to your vehicle, IF you are inside of it. MOST states require you to attempt to retreat first, even in your own home. If the intruder pursues or otherwise impedes escape, then a lethal response is allowed. 

"Stand your ground" laws have nothing to do with trespassing. 

If your life is being imminently threatened, that's self defense and doesn't matter where you are.

The spirit of all of these is to empower citizens to protect their lives and the lives of their loved ones, not to provide an excuse to kill people.
